awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Reimagining Teachers' Assessment Literacy Using Game-Based Learning Analytics
awd_abstract_narration:
The underlying premise of big data in education is that technology can help teachers and schools make data-informed decisions to better support student learning. As technology use in classrooms continues to increase, the data generated from technology use will also increase. Teachers will soon be required to develop a completely new set of assessment literacies around using the rich data and analytics provided in educational technology. However, little is known about how these kinds of data should be processed and presented to reflect teachers' decision-making and pedagogical desires. To address this gap, this project will reimagine teachers' assessment literacy in data- and technology-rich classrooms by leveraging a game-based assessment to help teachers become educated and critical consumers of analytics and algorithms embedded in educational technology. With more literate teachers, it is possible to maximize the potential of educational technology so that teachers can provide personalized and data-driven feedback during the process of learning.

This project will leverage an existing game-based assessment, Shadowspect, that measures Common Core math standards as well as cognitive and noncognitive skills such as spatial reasoning and persistence. The researchers will conduct design-based research to iteratively develop and embed interactive dashboards in the game and investigate how effectively different representations and features of the dashboards can support teachers' understanding and inform their actions. Additionally, the researchers will investigate how learning analytics can be used to directly support K-12 teachers' assessment practices and identify the knowledge and skills  teachers need to be successful in this area. The ultimate goal of the research is to understand teachers' assessment literacy in the era of big data and yield generalizable design principles for interactive dashboard tools that can facilitate teachers' data use without substantive external training. Ultimately, this research can lead to future investigations of how teachers' formative assessment practices might change when they have an increased understanding of learning analytics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This EAGER project had several major goals focused on exploring high-risk approaches to developing learning analytics and data visualizations for Shadowspect, an educational game, with the aim of benefiting both teachers and students. The project sought to bridge the gap between research on learning analytics and their practical application in classrooms. It also aimed to enhance teaching by providing valuable insights into student learning beyond academic performance, specifically through investigating the interaction between teachers' assessment literacy, data visualization, and learning analytics in the context of game-based assessment.

To achieve these goals, the project engaged in several significant activities. The research team embarked on a 12-month co-design process with teachers, involving extensive collaboration and input from educators. This process resulted in the creation of analytics models and data visualizations specifically tailored for Shadowspect. The game was implemented in one of the co-design teachers' classrooms to gain a qualitative understanding of how teachers would integrate and utilize the assessment models in their teaching environments. This hands-on experience helped shape the development of the learning analytics tools.

Throughout the co-design process, the project collected qualitative data, including discourse, field notes, and artifacts generated during the sessions. This data was extensively analyzed to establish design principles for future development and refinement of learning analytics tools. The insights gained from this analysis can inform future developments of actionable learning analytics and data visualizations in educational settings.

The project achieved significant results from its endeavors. The data collected during the co-design sessions yielded several publications, contributing to the scholarly knowledge in the field. Additionally, two prototypes of playful data visualizations were developed, showcasing the potential of incorporating engaging and interactive elements into learning analytics tools.

The EAGER project also facilitated professional development opportunities for graduate students and teacher participants. For graduate students, the project served as a context to advance their scholarship and conduct academic research. One master's thesis was written based on the project, and multiple academic products were produced with graduate students as co-authors, enhancing their scholarly pursuits.

For teacher participants, the project offered valuable insights and knowledge. Eight math teachers were recruited as design fellows, representing a mix of charter and public schools in Massachusetts. These teachers had diverse experiences and ranged from novice to expert educators. Through the co-design process, the design fellows gained a deeper understanding of co-design and design thinking, playful and non-traditional assessments, design trade-offs in assessment dashboards, and assessment data literacy. Their reflections highlighted the transformative impact of the project on their understanding of assessments and the importance of information presentation. The project provided a collaborative platform for teachers to share their perspectives and contribute to the development of tools that could improve instruction and assessment in the classroom.

The project also extended its impact beyond the immediate participants. It provided professional development opportunities for early-career STEM teachers in Wisconsin through the Early Career Teaching Institute at UW-Madison, further disseminating knowledge and empowering educators.

The results of the EAGER project were widely disseminated to communities of interest. The research team published a range of articles in prestigious journals and presented findings at conferences. The publications covered topics such as the application of learning analytics for spatial reasoning assessment, the affordances of multivariate learner modeling in game-based assessment, detecting sequences of actions and common errors in a geometry game, and the design and development of visualization dashboards to support teachers using educational games in the classroom.

In conclusion, this EAGER project successfully pursued its major goals by engaging in a co-design process with teachers, developing learning analytics tools, and exploring their potential in game-based assessment. The project yielded significant results, provided professional development opportunities, and disseminated knowledge through various publications and conference presentations. By bridging the gap between research and practice, the project made valuable contributions to the field of learning analytics and its practical application in educational settings
